Authors:
Sheng-Nan Zhang, Kevin D Hyde, E.B. Gareth Jones,
Ratchadawan Cheewangkoon, Jian-Kui Liu
Title:
Acuminatispora palmarum gen. et. sp. nov. from mangrove
habitats
Keywords:
2 new taxa, Dothideomycetes, Phylogeny, Sexual morph,
Taxonomy
Abstract:
Fungi play a vital role as decomposers in mangrove
ecosystems. A new ascomycete species, Acuminatispora palmarum,
inhabiting decayed petioles and rachides of palms in mangrove habitats,
is introduced in this paper, based on morphological and phylogenetic
evidence. Phylogenetic relationships of related taxa were inferred from
combined LSU, SSU, TEF1Î± and RPB2 sequences data, and the analyses
indicate that A. palmarum could be recognized as a distinct group, but
its familial placement needs to be further resolved. The morphological
characters of this new taxon are also different from other members in
Pleosporales by its deeply immersed ascomata with an erumpent short
neck, and fusiform ascospores having acute or narrowly pointed ends.
Acuminatispora gen. nov. (Pleosporales, incertae sedis) is therefore
established to accommodate the new taxon A. palmarum. Furthermore,
phylogenetic relationship of Acrocordiopsis and Caryospora were
discussed with a consideration of morphological characters.
